Wenn ein Sternchen "*" angezeigt wird, bedeutet das, dass der Abrechnungszeitraum erstellt ist, aber noch nicht abgeschlossen ist. Der Abrechnungszeitraum ist nun Abgeschlossen, was in der Übersicht im ersten Feld mit einem "A" ersichtlich ist. Wenn ein Sternchen "*" angezeigt wird, bedeutet das, dass der Abrechnungszeitraum erstellt ist, aber noch nicht abgeschlossen ist. Wenn weder "A" noch das Sternchen "*" angezeigt werden, ist der Abrechnungszeitraum verbrannt und muss durch den Support freigegeben werden Abgeschlossene Abrechnungszeiträume lassen sich auch über das Cowis-Hauptmenü in der Fibu-Schnittstelle finden.

title: Price Changes / Special Prices
text: To quickly and easily add special offers or other price changes to items, there is the "Automatic Price Change" feature. This can be found under Items -> Extras -> Booking / Edit Prices. First, select the items you want to add a special price (or price change). See also "Item Selection Options." Select the selected items (CTRL+a) or record -> select -> select all. Then go to Extras -> Book / Edit Prices -> Automatic Price Changes. If you receive a window with a currency query (customer-specific), select the appropriate currency. You will receive this window, in which you define the parameters for your desired price change. A field explanation can be found in a separate help article. In our example, we want to assign a special price to the selected item, which corresponds to a 30% reduction on the original selling price and is valid for the period June 15th - June 30th, 2025. (a duration is NOT mandatory, without a time specification the special price always applies until you remove it, with a date specification the special price only applies in this date range) After clicking OK, this window will appear, and the price change is complete. You can then uncheck the items. The special price will be displayed here, depending on your configuration. Otherwise, you can also find it in the item report list in the SP column.

title: Evaluations by inventory with sizes and colors (detailed item properties)
text: The easiest way to do this is to create a list in the Articles section. You mark the article or articles that you would like to have displayed. Then go to Print -> List Here you can then define what you want to have printed by activating the respective checkbox. the result then looks like this.

title: How to export a report to Excel
text: Cowis.Net does not export directly to Excel, but always creates a TXT file which you have to import into Excel. If you create an evaluation, tick the “Excel Export” checkbox. After the evaluation has been calculated, Cowis.Net must open a storage dialog (see image) If you do NOT see this save dialog, support must first activate the function. Function is activated: If the function is activated and you see the save dialog, enter a meaningful name for the file, leave the ending .TXT and save the export file. The file is available to you in the selected directory and you can import it into Excel

title: Printer for lists and evaluations
text: When printing lists or evlauations doesn't leed to anything, it might be that the wrong printer is choosen. Set the right printer in COWIS as follows: Artikel -> Einstellungen > Druckeinstellungen -> Druckparameter -> Choose "Standard"

title: What is the fastest way to evaluate the inventory?
text: The quickest way is the classic “warehouse, goods receipt and issue” evaluation. Once you have reached the classic evaluations, click on “New” or use “F5”. Then select the “warehouse, goods receipt and issue” report. If you only care about inventory as of today, fill in the date range from to with today's date. The top evaluation level is always “branch” (i.e. your company). You set this by using the drop-down menu in the breakdown and selecting the branch item. That's all you need to enter as basic information, all other fields are optional and are explained in a separate help area. Now click on OK or use F2 and the evaluation will be calculated. The result is an evaluation that shows you your current inventory in units, purchases and sales in the last three columns, broken down into your individual branches (if you have them) and the total. You can also put this on paper using the menu item Print -> Dataset.

title: Print preview of reports (A4) shows an incorrect size
text: If you are suddenly confronted with an unusual print preview in Cowis.Net Backoffice (see example) don't despair. You don't have to change anything in Cowis.Net!! Go to the Windows printer settings (usually it is enough to click on the Windows start area and search for printer Look for the check mark for standard printer Change the standard printer to your regular standard printer Start printing again and enjoy an evaluation

title: How to create a best of customer list by turnover
text: Open the merchandise management and click on "Analyses". Then follow the following click path: 1. Klassische Auswertungen 2. Neu 3. Verkäufe und Rohertrag 4. Gewünschten Zeitraum auswählen 5. Aufschlüsselung nach Kundennummer 6. Sortierung nach VK eff. 7. Haken bei Sortierung absteigend setzen 8. Haken bei Breite Liste setzen 9. OK klicken The top line in the evaluation that you then receive contains all customers without names (i.e. walk-in customers).

title: Inventur Datenübertrabung: MDE-Gerät wird von Kasse nicht erkannt
text: Wenn das MDE-Gerät zum Start einer Inventur nicht richtig mit der Kasse verbunden ist, können Sie folgende Schritte vornehmen: 1. Öffnen Sie "Funktion" in der Kasse 2. Klicken Sie anschließend auf System -> Kassenparameter 3. Klicken Sie anschließend auf "Alle Parameter" 4. Geben Sie im Suchfeld "SvMDeComPort" ein und bestätigen Sie mit der Eingabetaste (Enter) 5. Finde Sie den Parameter anhand den Werten "Typ" und "Dat" und klicken Sie diesen an 6. Geben Sie im Eingabefeld rechts oben die richtige ComPort Nummer ein Die richtige ComPort Nummer finden Sie im Windows Gerätemanager: - Drücken Sie die Tastenkombination "Windows-Logo" + "x" - Klicken Sie auf "Geräte-Manager" - Klicken Sie per Doppelklick auf "Anschlüsse" - Nun sehen Sie unter welchem ComPort das MDE-Gerät mit dem Namen "Silicon Labs..." angeschlossen ist. Wenn Sie sich unsicher sind, stecken Sie das MDE-Gerät aus und anschließend wieder ein und beobachten Sie welcher ComPort im Geräte-Manager verschwindet und wieder auftaucht. Handelt es sich beispielsweise wie im folgenden Screenshot um COM7, so müssen Sie im Eingabefeld in der Kasse (wie oben beschrieben) die Zahl "7" ein. Klicken Sie nach Eingabe der richtigen ComPort Nummer in der Kasse auf "OK" und anschließend auf "Speichern" Die Kasse startet sich nun automatisch neu und sollte das MDE-Gerät nun erkennen. Kontaktieren Sie den K3 Support, falls es dennoch nicht funktioniert.

title: Inventory with Cowis.Net Backoffice
text: 1. Definition Stocktaking is the recording of the quantity and value of all items actually present in the store. The value of the determined stock is a basis for the administration of the company and the tax authorities. For the tax office, the annual number of stocktakes carried out counts in order to check the stock corrections in terms of quantity and to confirm the stock for the annual financial statements. The stock corrections are intended to adjust the theoretical stock (in DdD Cowis backoffice) to the actual stock (in the store). This provides a basis for business management considerations of the store and simplifies restocking with goods. 2. Inventory tasks The first task of the inventory is a "target/actual comparison", with which differences between the stock of goods in DdD Cowis backoffice and the counted goods can be corrected. Such differences can arise due to Shrinkage: Handling errors by DdD Cowis backoffice or DdD Cowis pos, e.g: exchanges that were not booked back into Cowis and sold repeatedly Incorrect or "forgotten" store stock transfer Incorrect goods receipt A "target/actual comparison" can also be carried out as an inventory sampling in the current financial year, independently of the annual inventory. The principle is based on including all goods in stock on the day of the inventory (see "Inventory key date") in the inventory list. This inventory can include the entire range of goods. However, it is also possible to carry out a partial inventory. The second task is to print an inventory list for the balance sheet. In the inventory list, the stock of goods can be valued according to age groups, i.e. you can make the corresponding value corrections here. 3. Preparation in the stores Timely preparation of the stocktake is particularly important. In fact, preparation should begin as soon as the last stocktake has been completed. After each stocktake, all errors and deficiencies that have crept in should be recorded in writing in order to prevent the same errors from occurring again during the next stocktake. The actual preparation, however, should begin at least two months before the stocktaking. The better and more careful the preparation, the quicker the stocktaking will be and the more reliable the stocktaking will be. The basis for the preparation and recording phase is an inventory calendar.

title: Inventory - FAQ - The most frequently asked questions
text: Stocktaking How is the inventory data transferred from DdD Cowis pos to DdD Cowis backoffice? The data is transferred to COWIS using the "normal data exchange". You can see whether all data has been transferred by looking at the "Status" field in the inventory entry screen of the cash register. Inventory recording at the checkout counter Reference to deleted items in the inventory When entering an inventory, items that have already been deleted in Cowis can also be scanned at the checkout. As a result, these items are not displayed in the inventory in Cowis. In the past, this has resulted in differences in the quantities of the items concerned. In future, if an inventory with deleted items is read into Cowis from the cash register, a log will be displayed when entering the inventory area, which provides information about the items and their respective number of unaccounted counts. The red-colored info at the beginning of the log informs you in future about unknown recorded articles How can the inventory data be deleted from DdD Cowis pos and in DdD Cowis backoffice? The "old" inventory data can be deleted both in DdD Cowis backoffice and in DdD Cowis pos. In DdD Cowis pos, the inventory is recorded under "Function" in the "Data" tab using the "Record inventory" button. Here, existing inventory data can be deleted using the "Delete inventory" button. In DdD Cowis backoffice there is the menu item "Extras/Delete inventory data" in the Inventory area. How can an inventory be saved? You can save (export) an existing inventory under a freely selectable file name (e.g. c:\cowis\inv2011.txt) or read (import) a saved inventory in DdD Cowis backoffice under the menu item "Extras/Miscellaneous/Export/Import inventory". How is an inventory calculated back to December 31? Procedure: Confirm the "Inventory" item in the main menu. You are now in the inventory list, which should be empty. If old inventory data is still available, you will be asked whether this data should be deleted or not before the inventory is calculated. Then select the item "Extras/Other/Calculate inventory from master". After confirming this menu item, you will receive an information window and after confirming, you will be asked for the calculation date. Use the 01.01. of the year so that all postings that have been created on 31.12. are included. If this field is left blank, DdD Cowis backoffice takes the current date as the calculation date, i.e. the quantity of goods currently in stock is taken. If, however, you enter a date, the stocks that were in DdD Cowis backoffice on the morning of that day will be listed. Once the inventory list has been generated, the parts (items) can be valued and marked down. Note: When calculating an inventory, any inventory corrections made are not taken into account by the "target/actual comparison". Master calculations separable by branch and "Already taken over" feature The inventory area of Cowis has been revised. New features: The option "Calculate inventory from master" can now be carried out on individual stores. When creating a difference list, the user is warned if he wants to create difference lists for stores for which no inventory data has been recorded. The items in the inventory area now have an "already completed" status. A new column has been introduced for this purpose. If the stocktake is completed, i.e. the stocks are transferred, all entries are marked as "completed". Entries that have already been completed will NOT be taken into account for a further differences list and stock transfer! When creating a differences list, the user is now warned if there are "already completed" items in the inventory list. If you do not enter a key date when creating the differences list, the process is canceled. No difference list can be created without a key date! Option for store-specific calculation from the article master data New column: "Already adopted" Warning of difference list printout regarding unequal branches and "already completed" entries How can I calculate an inventory for a specific date? How are selections handled? An inventory can be calculated for any date from the article master. To do this, call up the menu item "Extras/Miscellaneous/Calculate inventory from master". You will then be asked for a calculation date. You can then specify whether selected items should be included in the inventory on this date. How do I take an inventory over several days? If you cannot take a complete inventory in one day, the inventory reference date is decisive. Everything that is in your store at the start of the inventory must be included in the inventory. Even if the stocktake takes place over several days, the stock that was present at the start of the stocktake always applies. This means that goods that are sold and have not yet been included in the inventory must be recorded manually. What happens to goods deliveries and sales during stocktaking? All parts that are sold during the inventory must be recorded. The following applies: what is in the shop/warehouse at the start of the inventory belongs in the inventory. This means that deliveries of goods that you received after the start of the physical inventory may not be included in the physical inventory. Note: If you post and label these goods deliveries, you could mark the labels with a colored dot, for example, so that you can distinguish these parts from the others. What about selections during the physical inventory? If you hand in selections during the physical inventory, these must be included in the physical inventory beforehand, as these parts were present in your stock at the start of the physical inventory. Selections that are returned during this time do not belong in the inventory, as they were not in the store/warehouse at the start of the inventory. Please also note the question on the previous page "How can I calculate an inventory on a specific date and how are selections treated? How is the inventory recorded in the mobile DdD Cowis backoffice? Stocktaking in the mobile DdD Cowis backoffice (laptop) is carried out in exactly the same way as at the COWIS head office. The data is transferred from the laptop to the head office using the normal data synchronization process. Stocktaking in several stores Differences due to incorrect or missing "store transfer" of goods. Should a "store transfer posting" be made retrospectively instead of an inventory correction? The answer to this question should actually be "yes", as the transfers can also be found in the statistics. But of course this means too much effort if you have several stores over a longer period of time. You should draw the attention of your sales staff to errors in advance by carrying out inventory spot checks and "educate" them to be more conscientious. How can you delete incorrectly transferred stock? It sometimes happens that incorrect stocks are transferred from the inventory to the item stock. To delete these corrections, you must first switch to the item master and select the menu item "Extras/posting/single posting". Now press the key combination "Shift-F9". You are now You are now in the "Movement history", i.e. all postings are listed here one after the other according to their date or time of origin. Find the inventory corrections (booking type "IK") for the corresponding day, select them and delete these bookings using the "F8" key or under "Data record/delete". Tips for recording with the MDE device If the COWIS inventory is recorded using an MDE device, please note the following information: The MDE device does not "know" the barcodes that you scan from the items. You can therefore also scan any barcode with the MDE device. There is no error message when scanning, but the MDE device accepts the barcode. This is particularly important if you are working with manufacturer barcodes. Incorrect or invalid codes are only recognized when you read the data into DdD Cowis backoffice. We therefore recommend the following procedure: Divide the inventory locations into small manageable units. Use the "COWIS inventory location" form from the appendix for each inventory location and count the number of items as a check BEFORE entering the goods. Tip: The check count when determining the inventory locations should not be carried out by the same person as the subsequent recording with the MDE device. Otherwise, the probability of the same item being overlooked twice is too high. Record the items with the PDC unit. Take the "Inventory recording location" form with you to the read-in station and read the data from the PDC unit into DdD Cowis backoffice. You will receive a read-in log with the number of "valid barcodes" with the manually counted check total. In the event of differences, you should not have the data processed in DdD Cowis backoffice, but should repeat the recording of this inventory location carefully. Further processing of the inventory How are the age groups for the deductions entered? How can automatic or manual markdowns be entered? The age groups for the automatic discounting of goods are entered under the menu item "File/Discounts after goods receipt". Here you can enter the period and the percentages. For example, if you enter 1 month / 5% and 2 months / 10%, all items that had their last goods receipt between one and two months after the calculation date (you can enter this when you call up "Extras/Automatic markdown") will be marked down by 5%. All articles whose last goods receipt was more than 2 months ago are then written off at 10%. For manual markdowns, you should first select the desired items (e.g. a product group) in the inventory list, mark them and then call up the menu item "Extras/Manual markdown". Here you can then enter either a percentage markdown (all parts are marked down by this percentage) or a total after markdown (the total is allocated to all parts as a percentage). How is an inventory list printed out (by branch)? The inventory list can be created by calling up the menu item "Print/Inventory list". You will then see a screen in which you can specify whether the list should be limited to one store. By entering merchandise group locations, you can specify how precisely the list of items should be broken down by merchandise group. Delimitation of goods on consignment To ensure that goods on consignment in DdD Cowis backoffice can be given special consideration in the inventory (e.g. when printing out the inventory list), the items must be specially marked in DdD Cowis backoffice, e.g. using a special keyword field. This allows a separate difference list to be created for these goods (selection according to this keyword field). An item list can be created for these goods to delimit the value of the goods in accounting. How is a list of age groups printed out? You can obtain a list of the age groups (discount rates) under the menu item "Print/Specials/Overview by age group". Difference list How is a difference list created? How can the differences list be limited to individual stores? To create the difference list, confirm the menu item "Inventory/Extras/Create difference list". In the subsequent "Selection" screen, the date of the first inventory day must be entered in the "Key date" field. If you want to create a difference list for a specific store, you must enter or select it in the "Store" field. Once the difference list has been created, the "Transfer stock" menu item is active. Please note that the "Transfer stocks" item always refers to the previously created differences list. To be on the safe side, this only applies as long as DdD Cowis backoffice is open. After a restart, you must first create a difference list again. What is the key date? A stocktake is always a snapshot of your inventory. However, this changes in the course of the stocktaking, provided that business operations continue. For DdD Cowis backoffice, the moment of inventory is the morning of the inventory date. This means that all items that are or were in your stock on the morning of the inventory date must be included in the inventory. So if you start the inventory in the morning, it's quite simple: the key date is the morning of the day on which you started the inventory. However, if you start the inventory in the evening after closing time, for example, the reference date is the following day, as the inventory in the evening is the same as the inventory in the morning of the following day. How do you work with different cut-off dates if, for example, you take stock of several stores in succession on different days? If you take stock in several stores on different days, there are of course several cut-off dates. Here you must pay particular attention to which day you started in which store so that the correct key date is entered when creating the difference lists for the different stores. Can an inventory only be taken for part of the goods? The goods can be inventoried completely or in parts. Here it is important that you also "inform" DdD Cowis backoffice when creating the differences list that it is not a complete inventory (by default, DdD Cowis backoffice assumes a complete inventory). To do this, you can either work with a selection when creating the list of differences or activate the "Partial inventory" switch. For further details, please refer to the documentation under "Difference list - partial inventory". Danger of partial inventories, items not counted are not corrected to zero. If you carry out an inventory with DdD Cowis backoffice and activate the "Partial inventory" switch when creating the difference list, this means that items that no longer have any stock, but have a stock greater than zero in DdD Cowis backoffice and were therefore not counted during the inventory (e.g. because the item was stolen) are not changed in the stock. Only those items that have been included in the inventory list at least once are taken into account in the partial inventory. If you want to correct these items definitively, you must give DdD Cowis backoffice the opportunity to recognize them. This can be done, for example, via a partial inventory of one (or more) suppliers or one (or more) product groups. When creating the differences list, you can then select the merchandise categories or suppliers in the selection mask and leave the "Partial inventory" switch deactivated. Where do inventory differences come from? Why is it so important to clear negative stock levels (or clarify the errors) before the inventory? Negative stock levels are an indication of errors in the workflow with DdD Cowis backoffice. The most common causes of negative stock levels are Incorrect store stock transfers (not posted or posted to the wrong store). Incorrect procedure for exchanges or complaints at the checkout. Incorrect definition of "with goods movement" for returns. Poorly recorded inventory from the previous year (parts were not or not completely included in the inventory). Goods receipts were posted to the wrong store (e.g. to the warehouse instead of directly to the sales store). Before the stocktake, you should always clarify the negative stocks in the stores and correct them if necessary (make up for store stock transfers, check returns and goods receipts) What causes negative stock levels shortly after a stock transfer? If there are negative item stocks directly after an inventory and stock transfer, these parts were probably forgotten to be included in the inventory. The item stock was therefore corrected downwards and when these parts are subsequently sold, the stock goes into the negative. In this case, you should either make a manual stock correction or (if you have the appropriate authorization) delete the previously created inventory correction postings. In the following example, an item was delivered in 2 sizes (XL and L) on 18.12.2011 and size L was forgotten to be counted in the physical inventory. The stocks were transferred on 01.01.2012 (IK posting is created by DdD Cowis backoffice one day earlier, i.e. on 31.12.2011) and then both sizes were sold on 05.01.2004. This naturally results in negative stock in size L, as this item was sold although it was not normally in stock.

title: Practical measures to minimize inventory differences
text: For what and for whom is this documentation intended? This documentation is intended to serve as a buffet of ideas to help you minimize your inventory discrepancies throughout the year. We have compiled practical tips from several different sources to help you minimize both staff and customer theft, avoid the manipulation of inventory results and generally gain more control over your company's flow of goods. Some of these measures will certainly be of interest to every textile retailer, while others will only be of interest to certain types of organization (chain stores, discount stores, specialist retailers, etc.). Choose the measures that seem suitable for you. It is better to implement one measure consistently than not to try many at all. Definition of Stocktaking is the recording of the quantity and value of all items actually present in the store. The value of the determined stock is a basis for the tax authorities and the company's administration. For the tax office, the annual number of stocktakes carried out counts in order to check the stock corrections in terms of quantity and to confirm the stock for the annual financial statements. The stock corrections are intended to adjust the theoretical stock to the actual stock (in the store). This results in better re-sorting of the goods. General principles Taking inventory is often perceived as a tedious chore. This is often the opinion of not only the employees of a company, but also the entrepreneurs. The inventory is not just an inventory of goods. It is also a valuable business and tax management tool. There are two requirements for the inventory: The records must provide an accurate overview of the warehouse. However, this requires a correct and complete inventory. The inventory must be a correct document for checking the profit determination by the tax office. Therefore, the inventory is primarily a document for the entrepreneur and only then is the required document for the tax office. Both the preparation and execution of the inventory is extremely important so that a meaningful inventory result can be determined. The inventory is the most important basis for the annual financial statements to determine assets and to answer the question of whether profit or loss was made. The KER success sheets show the inventory in the warehouse at the end of the year, but not the actual inventory and, above all, no basis for the evaluation. If there is no perfect inventory, not only the annual financial statements for the past financial year are incorrect, but also those for the next year; The ending inventory is incorrect for the past fiscal year, and the opening inventory is incorrect for the following year. According to the study “Inventory Differences 2002” by the Cologne Euro Handelsinstitut (EHI), inventory differences in the German textile trade were 1.33% of gross sales in 2000 and 1.23% in 2001. This means that the textile retail trade is above the average for the entire German retail trade, which recorded inventory differences of 1.14% in 2000 and 1.12% in 2001. The pain threshold for an inventory difference is one percent of gross sales (at sales prices). For companies with a turnover of up to €2.5 million, this pain threshold is as low as 0.5% sales of turnover. Differences beyond this require a precise analysis, because with an extremely tight tax result and a negative business result, higher differences can no longer be accepted. Unless it is a case of incorrect inventory taking, other organizational reasons or theft (customers, staff) must be the cause of this return killer. Planing By law, an annual inventory must be carried out in every store. However, 12 months is too long a period to be able to take the appropriate measures in good time in the event of weaknesses in the store. The period of control inventories ranges from 13 weeks to a maximum of 26 weeks. The better the result, the longer the period until the next stocktake can be. Preparation in the stores If the inventory is carried out with due consideration, the figures provide a retrospective overview of the extent to which the business planning for the past financial year was correct or incorrect, as well as indications for better new planning in the following year. In principle, timely preparation of the inventory is particularly important. In fact, preparation should begin as soon as the last inventory has been completed. After each stocktake, all errors and shortcomings that have crept in should be recorded in writing to prevent the same errors from occurring again during the next stocktake. The actual preparation, however, should begin at least two months before the stocktaking deadline. The better and more careful the preparation, the faster the stocktaking will be and the fewer sources of error there will be. Source: BTE - Specialist documentation - Inventory and evaluation of stock in the textile retail trade Preventing theft General information Theft has become a major loss item for companies in recent years. According to various studies in the retail sector, the losses can be broken down as follows: 10% due to internal errors (e.g. incorrect labels) 40% due to customer theft 50% due to staff theft A precise analysis of staff theft produces the following figures: 10% in the reserve (stored goods) 35% in the store 55% during checkout (manipulation) The best means of combating theft are and remain remain customer service and sales. Checkout A cash register audit should always be carried out every time there is a change of sales assistant. The corresponding receipt should be signed by the two persons concerned. This will immediately reveal any discrepancies. Cash register accounting Do not count money at the till in a way that is visible or observable from the outside. Remove money from the till several times a day and lock it in the safe. There should never be more than 1000 euros in the till. Do not change money. The cash register should either be monitored or locked. Do not allow unauthorized persons behind the till. Keep the keys to the safe and the cash register on your person. Never keep them on the same bunch of keys! Bank transactions Always have money brought to the bank by persons of legal age. Do not transport money in company-owned bags. The routes to the bank or deposit and collection times vary. Deposit cash daily. Generally only deposit change in the safe. Security service: Before the handover: Turnover day/day of the week Safebag no. Amount in Euro Pick up on During the handover: Driver's badge no. Name of the store employee Signature of the store employee Theft How can you prevent shoplifting? The aim should be to prevent shoplifting by keeping staff alert. The article surveillance should only have a deterrent effect. However, the primary goal is not to expose shoplifters with merchandise security, but rather to deter them in advance of the crime and thus prevent them from entering the store at all. Any article surveillance system that aims to reduce inventory differences caused by shoplifting is only effective if it is meaningfully supported by employees. Dishonest or suspicious customers can often be recognized by their behavior: The customer looks around nervously and tries to stay in places in the sales area where he cannot be observed. The customer primarily observes the surroundings and is less concerned with the goods. The customer is “protected” by other people who distract the staff. He often changes places and often returns to the same poles. He whispers to other people or gives signs. He walks hunched over because he is hiding something under his clothes. However, being vigilant can help prevent shoplifting. For conspicuous customers, you can, for example, proceed as follows: Greet every person who comes into the branch. Speak to the customer. Make eye contact with the customer. Keep an eye on conspicuous customers. Special attention is paid to the fitting rooms (cabins). Choose a word or phrase that you can use to call a colleague for help in an emergency. Attention is also required if the customer carries large bags or wears conspicuously loose clothing. Gangs of thieves remain in line of sight and can use diversionary tactics to steal with less risk than solo perpetrators. So inform additional employees to observe. Always make sure that the goods are sorted and tidy so that you have a good overview of the store. In order to unsettle the thief, you have to be unpredictable: be present, mobile and change activities more often. Manipulation exchanges How can you prevent manipulation in exchanges? Adhere to the following rules of the game: Only managers have the cash register keys. The keys must be carried on your body. Payments may only be made using your own salesperson number. Receipts that the customer forgets must be destroyed immediately. Exchanges can only be carried out by managers. This is not possible. Exchanges with secured goods and a receipt signed (by the customer and sales staff) must be placed in the checkout area until it has been checked by an authorized person. Always carry out exchanges in the presence of a second person (if possible) and have both people sign immediately. Note the reasons for the exchange and whether it is an exchange for goods or a refund by hand on the receipt. When making an exchange, the customer's name, address and telephone number should be entered on the receipt and signed by them. Exchanges should not be carried out without a receipt (if there is no longer a receipt, the customer's ID should be presented). Include the number and value of exchanges in the cash book.

title: Recording options
text: DdD Cowis Backoffice manual (with or without table) Select “Inventory” in the main menu to access the inventory list. In order to be able to record the inventory positions here, please press the [F5] key or click on “New”. If you work with branch management, the overview list of all branches appears first. Here you can select the branch for which you would like to receive the goods. After selecting the store, the “Create new inventory” input window appears. The individual inventory items are recorded here. In the “Quantity” field, the suggested quantity is “1”. Entering the items in the “Item ID” field can be done in different ways. Manual entry of the goods in a size table The prerequisite here is that a “Y” is entered in the “Recording with size table” field under the “Settings/Standard settings” menu item. If this function is activated in the "Settings", you will get the "Table recording" window after selecting the branch. Here you can confirm the point with the table. An overview list of all articles then opens. Once you have confirmed the item you want, the quantity can be entered using the size chart. The entries are saved with [F2] or “Save”. DdD Cowis back office via scanner By reading the barcode labels with a scanner (barcode reader). A notice: If the barcode on individual parts is not readable or the label has been lost, these parts can also be recorded by entering the “Item ID”, if necessary with characteristics (e.g. size, color). DdD Cowis Pos via scanner By reading the barcode labels on the DdD Cowis pos. Tap on the “Function” button and then on the “Data” tab and then on the “Enter inventory” button. Here the goods can be read in by “scanning” the labels or by entering the “Item ID” (if necessary with size, color, etc.). After the inventory has been taken at the checkout, the data is transferred to the “COWIS headquarters” via remote data transmission as part of a normal data exchange. The transferred inventory items are marked with a star at the checkout. This prevents inventory items from being accidentally transferred twice. Once you have completed the inventory in DdD Cowis backoffice, i.e. after the “target/actual comparison”, the recorded inventory items can be deleted again at the cash register (menu item “Function/Data/Enter inventory/Delete inventory”). DdD Cowis back office via MDE device The barcode labels are read with an MDE. Once recorded, the collected data is transferred to the system. Please contact us regarding makes, prices and handling of the “MDE’s”. Mobile DdD Cowis Back Office In the inventory area, goods can be recorded in the same way as at the “COWIS headquarters”. After recording, the data is transferred from the laptop to the “COWIS headquarters” via data comparison.

title: Treatment of selections
text: Selections that are managed in the DdD Cowis back office (e.g. through “payment method selection” at the DdD Cowis pos) do not need to be included in the inventory. These selections are automatically taken into account in the inventory during the “target/actual comparison”. The following example illustrates the procedure: Inventory in DdD Cowis backoffice 9 parts Selection DdD Cowis back office 1st chapter Total inventory 10 parts Inventory list (counted) 9 parts Considered selection 1st chapter Inventory difference no Selections that are not managed with DdD Cowis backoffice, but manually and that are made on the inventory date Customers must be included in the inventory. Instead of the 9 counted parts, there must be 10 parts in the inventory list. Here is the example again: Inventory in DdD Cowis backoffice 9 parts Selection in DdD Cowis backoffice 0 parts Manually managed selection 1st chapter Total inventory 10 parts Inventory list 9 parts Selection +1 part (will be added to the inventory later) Inventory difference no If you want to print an inventory list for the balance sheet, the selections managed with DdD Cowis back office must be subsequently recorded in the inventory list after the “target/actual comparison” or you can have an inventory calculated from the item master.

title: Movement of goods during inventory
text: Important: If you want to take inventory over several days, you must note the following: Goods that leave the store (sales, exchanges, store de-bookings or selections) must be included in the inventory list (the goods were already in stock on the morning of the inventory date). Goods that come into the store (goods deliveries, store bookings) may not be included (the goods were not in stock on the morning of the inventory date). Normal operations can continue during an inventory. Goods can be sold and rebooked as usual, deliveries can be made. One thing to note here is that all parts that are present on the first inventory day, i.e. the deadline, must also be counted. The key is to enter the “inventory date”. When generating the difference list, DdD Cowis backoffice compares the actual (counted) inventory with the date entered (“inventory key date”).

title: Further processing of the recorded inventory items
text: Difference list Please ensure that no employee creates bookings while the difference list is being created. These can be changing/adding goods receipts, returns, delivery notes or invoices. In this case, the bookings will be removed and recreated when saved. If you then create a new difference list, differences will arise! When the difference list is created, the items are automatically checked for booking consistency checked. Since this check can take a considerable amount of time depending on the database size, this function can be used can also be deactivated. However, this setting is not recommended. Once all parts have been counted and included in the COWIS inventory, a difference list is created. When creating this list, the counted parts are compared with the inventory listed in DdD Cowis backoffice. You will then receive an overview of the parts for which the counted inventory does not match the inventory of DdD Cowis backoffice. The difference list is created before the “target/actual comparison” of the inventory. This gives you the opportunity to control inventory taking. If you confirm the item “Extras/Create Difference List”, you will first see the “Selection” window, which contains the following fields: Deadline: Enter the inventory deadline here. This entry is always required if the inventory date differs from the current date and goods have moved in the meantime. Selection fields: Article ID ... Branch number: You can limit this if you only want to create a difference list for some of the inventory items. This can be, for example, a branch, product group or even a supplier. If you have carried out a complete inventory and want to compare it with the inventory in DdD Cowis backoffice, you can leave these fields blank. Partial recording: By entering “Y/N” or by clicking this box, you indicate whether it is a partial or complete recording. In the case of a partial inventory, when generating the difference list, COWIS only takes into account goods of which at least 1 part was recorded in the inventory. If it is a partial recording, a “J” must definitely be entered here. Carry out an item consistency check: When the difference list is created, the items are automatically checked for booking consistency checked. Since this check can take a considerable amount of time depending on the database size, this function can be used can also be deactivated. However, this setting is not recommended. Input mask for the difference list If inexplicably high differences occur in the finished difference list, it serves as the basis for a further check of the inventory recording (parts may have been forgotten). If some parts are still found (seasonal goods packed in boxes, goods in the seasonal warehouse, selections not managed with DdD Cowis back office, etc.), these can now be added to the inventory list and a new difference list created. The list can also be printed out directly after creation for better control. Target/actual comparison Once all inventory positions have been checked using the difference list and corrected if necessary, the inventory stock is adopted as inventory. To do this, please select the item “Extras/Adopt stocks”. Only with this step are the final inventory corrections made. These corrections appear in the respective item history as a booking type “IK”, i.e. a positive or negative booking is created in the history depending on the difference. The booking date of the automatically generated IK bookings is 1 day before the inventory key date entered when creating the difference list. A notice: The “Adopt stocks” item is only active immediately after the difference list has been created. So if you close DdD Cowis backoffice and restart it, a difference list must first be created again. This function is for security purposes so that incorrect stocks are not unintentionally taken over. Only goods that are displayed in the difference list are also taken into account when “transferring stocks”. For example, if you have restricted a difference list to a specific branch, then only the differences from this branch will be corrected. Export/import inventory Under the menu item “Extras/Other/Inv. “export/import” you can save (export) an existing inventory under a freely selectable file name (e.g. c:\cowis\inv2011.txt) or re-import (import) a saved inventory into DdD Cowis backoffice. If you want to import a saved inventory into DdD Cowis backoffice and there is still data in the inventory, you will be asked whether you want to delete the existing inventory or whether the data should be appended there. The “Export inventory for Excel” option creates a text file that can be opened in the “Excel” program. This file cannot be imported back into COWIS! Export\import inventory selection dialog Calculate inventory from the item master DdD Cowis backoffice offers another option for filling the inventory list with data using the “Create inventory from the item master” method. The goods are not counted, but the inventory is taken from the inventory management. DdD Cowis backoffice transfers all stocks to the inventory list. Upon request, you can specify here whether selections should also be included in this calculation or not. DdD Cowis backoffice offers you this function, as the tax authorities only require a physical inventory every 3 years. (Keyword: permanent inventory) Method: Confirm the “Inventory” item in the main menu You are now in the inventory list, which should be empty. If old inventory data still exists, you will receive a query before the inventory is calculated as to whether this data should be deleted or not. Then select the item “Extras/Other/Calculate inventory from master”. After confirming this menu item, you will receive an information window and after confirming you will be asked for the calculation date (key date). If this field is left blank, DdD Cowis backoffice will use the current time as the calculation date, i.e. the quantity of goods currently in stock will be adopted. On the other hand, if you enter a date, the stocks that were in COWIS on the morning of that day will be listed. After the inventory list has been created, the parts (positions) can be evaluated and knocked off. A notice: When calculating an inventory, any inventory corrections that may arise from the “target/actual comparison” are not taken into account taken into account. Print inventory list In the inventory area, some adjustments were made in connection with negative items: After the "Calculate inventory from master" option has been executed, user information now appears if there are negative items in the inventory. Negative inventory positions are now colored red in the inventory area. A setting “Consider negative stocks” has been added to the options menu for the “Print --> List” function. Positions with negative stocks are now only taken into account in the list printout if this new option has been activated. On the result message of the "Total inventory" function, a distinction is now made between the inventory total with negative stocks and the inventory total without negative stocks. Both totals are now listed separately. Items with negative stocks are now colored red in the inventory area. The option “Consider negative stocks” has been added to the “Inventory --> Print --> List” mask. By clicking on the question mark you will receive an explanation of this option.

title: Assessment and presentation
text: Inventory list for accounting depreciation What does “writing off” the goods actually mean? When “depreciating” the value of the goods is adjusted based on age. In DdD Cowis backoffice you can make these value corrections in the inventory list after the “target/actual comparison”. The value corrections in the inventory list can be implemented in various ways. For these options, you should have recorded your complete inventory (physical inventory or have it calculated from the “item master”), as partial inventory only makes sense for checking the “target/actual inventory”. Important: Please note that before the goods are written off, the selections managed with DdD Cowis backoffice are first included in the inventory list (manually or by calculation from the item master). Automatic and manual transcription The “Write-off (automatic and manual)” functions are available to you in DdD Cowis backoffice under the “Extras” menu item as options for editing the inventory list for balance sheet accounting: Automatically: First, a list of age groups must be created under “File/Deductions after goods receipt”. There you can enter the “age (goods receipt)” in months and the associated “deductions” in percent. When executing the “Extras/Write-off (automatic)” item, DdD Cowis backoffice automatically calculates the markdowns for the individual parts based on the goods receipts in the inventory list and the values entered. Before this point is carried out, you will be asked to enter a reference date. If you leave this field empty, DdD Cowis backoffice uses the current system date as the reference date. A NOTICE: If you enter e.g. 1 month = 2% and 2 months = 4% in the list of discounts, this means that DdD Cowis backoffice discounts items that are 1-2 months old with 2% and all 2 months and older with 4% . If you would also like to mark down goods that are less than a month old, please leave the “Month” field in the “Markdowns after goods receipt” list empty and enter the desired percentage behind it. Manually: This function is applied to the current article or the marked article. Since “discounts” are usually applied to entire product groups with the same value, it makes sense to summarize them beforehand. You can group the article or product groups that are to be discounted with the same percentage beforehand by marking them with the space bar. Then please confirm the point “Write down (manually)”. The “Inventory deductions” window opens. There you can either enter a “deduction in %” or a “total after deduction”. When you enter a value in one of the two fields, the other field is automatically included. TIP! You can also select the articles in order to then mark them and knock them down manually. Item properties can be selected in the inventory Overview by age group Under the menu item “Print/Special/Overview by age group” you can have the total items sold printed out. Print inventory list When all value corrections have been made, you can start printing the inventory list under the menu item “Print/List”.

title: Basic information for setting up a transport route for the XRechnung / ERechnung
text: The customer must provide us with this information. - E-mail address (e.g. Rechnung@, ERechnung@ or similar) - E-mail server reception protocol (IMAP / POP3) - Name of the receiving server - Port of the receiving server - User of the receiving server (usually the e-mail address) - Password of the user of the receiving server - Name of the sending server - Port of the sending server - User of the sending server (usually the e-mail address) - Password of the user of the sending server - E-mail address of the sender (e.g. Rechnung@...) - SSL encryption (yes/no) - Base64 encoding of the access data - ServerCertificateValidationCallback (yes/no)

title: the first steps to set up the ERechnung / XRechnung
text: These steps can and must be carried out mainly by the customer. The transport route is created by DdD retail (Cowis Support) Carry out an UPDate in Cowis.Net. The version must be at least 6.4.60 from November 25th, 2024 This is how you read an update in Cowis.Net Backoffice If you don't already have one, create an email address for sending invoices (e.g. Rechnung@, ERechnung@, XRechnung@, etc.) Have the access data for this email account ready or get support from your network administrator. Support needs the following information from you to set up the transport route in Cowis.Net Backoffice: - E-mail server reception protocol (IMAP / POP3) - Name of the receiving server - Port of the receiving server - User of the receiving server (usually the e-mail address) - Password of the user of the receiving server - Name of the sending server - Port of the sending server - User of the sending server (usually the e-mail address) - Password of the user of the sending server - E-mail address of the sender (e.g. Rechnung@...) - SSL encryption (yes/no) - Base64 encoding of the access data - ServerCertificateValidationCallback (yes/no) Later in Cowis.Net Backoffice, the whole thing will look like this. The support or delivery team will take care of the setup. This should be the first step because you have to enter this transport route ID for each B2G address, together with the routing ID. It would be double work if you had to enter the routing ID first and then enter the transport route ID afterwards. When the transport route has been created. Enter it together with the routing ID in the B2G address. You will receive the routing ID from your customer. (When creating a new process in the orders area, the routing ID is "pulled" from the address) Your address in the addresses area in Cowis.Net If you have several branches, this applies to every branch from which you create invoices. In the addresses area, enter the address of the sending branch. You do NOT have to fill this address with an address type: MANDATORY fields are: Company Name1+Name2, telephone and email Example: Branch 1 Branch 2 Enter this address ID (in this case 1 and 2) behind the respective branch You go to Article -> File -> Branches You select the branch to be changed with Change and enter the created address ID Branch1 Branch 2 Please check whether your VAT ID is stored in the print parameters area in order processing (if not, please enter it): Orders -> Settings -> Print settings -> Print parameters Whenever you are unsre, please don't hesitate to contact your Cowis Support

title: B2B XRechnung setup in Cowis.Net back office
text: You must have the latest Cowis.Net UPDate (at least 6.4.60 from 12/3/2024 12:50) This is how you read in an UPDate in Cowis.Net Backoffice Currently (December 4, 2024), error-free transfer of the XRechnung in the B2B area is only possible if you do not use gross items. So if you have an activated checkbox for gross in the screenshot when creating an invoice, the XRechnung will not be validated correctly. We are working on a solution. Gross must not be active for correct transport! !!If you have NOT activated a checkbox here, you can start or continue with the introduction of the XRechnung in B2B traffic!! START Support has already set up the transport route for you and activated the necessary parameter, if not, contact Support@K3btg.com immediately by email for an appointment. (If you are not sure, contact support) Your address in the addresses area in Cowis.Net If you have several branches, this applies to every branch from which you create invoices. In the addresses area, enter the address of the sending branch. You do NOT have to fill this address with an address type: MANDATORY fields are: Company Name1+Name2, telephone and email Example: Branch 1 Branch 2 Enter this address ID (in this case 1 and 2) behind the respective branch You go to Article -> File -> Branches You select the branch to be changed with Change and enter the created address ID Branch1 Branch 2 Please check whether your VAT ID is stored in the print parameters area in order processing (if not, please enter it): Orders -> Settings -> Print settings -> Print parameters Customer addresses: We know that it is a lot of work for you, but another solution was not technically feasible. You must revise and complete every customer address that receives an XRechnung from you in the B2B area. You go to Addresses in the Cowis.Net Back Office You select the address to be changed with F7 or Change You must enter a customer email address in the Contacts area for receiving XRechnungen (ERechnungen) To do this, go to Edit on the Contacts tab in change mode Here, go to NEW Create a contact that is unique to you, e.g. B2B invoice email address Enter a description Enter an email address - Additional data -> Submit XRechnung You will NOT receive a confirmation of sending as a notification! If you want, you can look in the LOG directory below your Cowis.Net directory, a file called XRechnung.log will be created there If you double-click on the LOG, it will open, at the end of the file you will see the most recent entry In the Cowis.Net directory there is a folder called XRechnung.xml This is where the sent XRechnung invoices are archived Your customer receives an email with the XRechnung attached (currently without a subject, but we are still checking whether it is legally permissible to send a subject) As this topic is very dynamic, always pay attention to information about new UPDates in the info area

title: Attaching PDF invoice to XRechnung B2B
text: This function is only implemented for the "Microsoft Print to PDF" printer. From program version Cowis.Net Backoffice 6.4.60 13.12.2024 in the customer area on the Wholesale tab, in addition to the B2B invoice settings, you can choose whether you want to attach a PDF. There are 3 options; setting 2 is recommended for B2B shipping. A logical printer must be created in the system settings. A form for shipping must be defined in the orders. As this cannot be done by you without further ado, you should contact us if necessary.
